PROFESSOR: Today we're going to
continue our discussion of

methods of integration. The method that I'm going to
describe today handles a whole

class of functions of
the following form. You take P (x) / Q (x)
and this is known
as a rational function.

And all that means is that
it's a ratio off two

polynomials, which are these
functions P ( x) and Q ( x).

We'll handle all such functions
by a method which is known as partial fractions.

And what this does is, it splits
P / Q into what you
could call easier pieces.

So that's going to be some
kind of algebra. And that's what we're going
to spend most of our time doing today.

I'll start with an example. And all of my examples
will be illustrating

more general methods. The example is to integrate the

So now, here's the difficulty
that is going to arise. The difficulty is that I can
start with this function,

which is perfectly manageable. And than I can add these
two functions together.

The way I add fractions. So that's getting a common
denominator.
